medium: Pen and brown ink with brush and grey-brown wash over black chalk
creditline: Bequest of Dan Fellows Platt, Class of 1895
signed: Signed in brown ink, lower right center (on bed rail): Dom° Tiepolo f. [in artist's hand]

titles.title: Quack Doctors Attend a Stout Man in Harlequin Costume

texts.textentryhtml: Constructed like a stage set, this minimal interior is enlivened by striped fabrics and such domestic details as the bed warmer, chamber pot, and enema—the latter brandished by one of the figures on the left. The center of attention is a portly and disheveled middle-aged man whose pulse is being taken by a mincing physician sprouting donkey’s ears, a whimsical detail signifying the artist’s caustic view of the medical profession. This theatrical tableau belongs to a series of highly finished drawings, called Scenes from Contemporary Life, which the Venetian painter Domenico Tiepolo (son of Giambattista) executed toward the end of his life. Made for his private interest and amusement, these gently satirical works portray a cast of characters from all walks of life engaged in social and domestic activities.

Both patient and doctor are ridiculed in this tableau—one of a series of highly finished drawings, called Scenes of Contemporary Life, in which Tiepolo gently satirized the social and domestic activities of his fellow middle-class Venetians. Here an overweight and disheveled man is the center of attention, as his pulse is taken by a fawning physician sprouting donkey ears—a symbol of ignorance, indicating the artist’s caustic view of the medical profession.

Sotheby's, sale June 30, 1925;

Dan Fellows Platt;

Bequested to Princeton University Art Museum
